options.label: D

options.label: E
options.svg: <svg viewBox="0 0 100 100" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g fill="black" stroke="white" stroke-width="2"><polygon points="35,15 65,15 85,35 85,65 65,85 35,85 15,65 15,35"/><polygon points="50,30 72,40 72,60 50,70 28,60 28,40"/><circle cx="30" cy="25" r="4"/><circle cx="70" cy="25" r="4"/><circle cx="80" cy="50" r="4"/><circle cx="20" cy="50" r="4"/><circle cx="30" cy="75" r="4"/><circle cx="70" cy="75" r="4"/></g></svg>

explanation:
The rule governing the figures has two parts. First, the number of vertices (corners) on the inner shape must be two less than the number of vertices on the outer shape. Second, the number of small circles must be equal to the number of vertices on the inner shape. 

A: Outer hexagon (6 vertices), inner square (4 vertices). 6 - 2 = 4. There are 4 circles. This is correct.
B: Outer pentagon (5 vertices), inner triangle (3 vertices). 5 - 2 = 3. There are 3 circles. This is correct.
C: Outer heptagon (7 vertices), inner square (4 vertices). 7 - 2 = 5. The inner shape should have 5 vertices, but it has 4. This is incorrect.
D: Outer square (4 vertices), inner line (2 vertices). 4 - 2 = 2. There are 2 circles. This is correct.
E: Outer octagon (8 vertices), inner hexagon (6 vertices). 8 - 2 = 6. There are 6 circles. This is correct.

Therefore, figure C is the odd one out as it breaks the first part of the rule.
